crossroad:
You've arrived at a crossroads in your journey.
Your car's engine hums in the background.
Displayed before you is an intricate series of
intertwining woods and ever-shifting grass.

The woods themselves feel alive,
swaying gently as a gentle breeze passes overhead.
Dying leaves fall from their branches.

The trail you have been following for some
time stops short in front of a singular tree.
It looks down on you.

You look up at the tree.
Its branches lack the leaves that its nearby
siblings tout. A small shoe, no larger than an infant's,
hangs by its laces from one of the tree's limbs.

Upon closer inspection, you find that with
very little effort, you can grab the shoe
if you so wish.
*Please drag the shoe into the backpack.*
pickUpShoe:
You grab the shoe. It's worn from use.
Mud and dirt cover the laces.
You're not quite sure why you grabbed it.

Best not to dwell on that decision,
look on the bright side; you have a shoe now.

*You may drag certain items into your bag
when you are searching in an area.
There is no pressure on collecting anything.
Please do whatever you feel like.*
Feel free to depart when you are ready.
crossroad_continue:
The tree, no longer an interesting obstacle
in your journey, is blotted out of your
mind as you continue forward, moving past
the finished trail and into the forest proper.

The crunch of branches underfoot radiates
through the woods, the distant sound
of a woodpecker returning its call.

In the distance, you see it.
Your destination.
Your goal.

It stands tall, taller than you imagined.
Of course, in reality most towers are larger
than you envision them to be, sturdier too.
It breaks the cloud-line.

In fact, now that you've taken note of it, you
find that it is the only object to pierce the
dense canopy of the woods. Additionally,
you can't even see the top.

As your gaze falls back to the forest,
you notice that a fog has begun overtaking the
ground layer.

It appears that soon, this tower
will be your only guide.
Best to keep that in mind.
Last chance to decide where to go now.
crossroad_leave:
You've left the forest.
Perhaps it was for the best.

FIN - I'm a coward.

Continue to go back to Menu.
crossroad_fog: You have trekked into the fog.

An immediate sense of regret washes over you.
As you turn to retrace your steps, you find
that the woods have already shifted behind you.

The tower, however, remains stationary.
You dig through your pockets.
*Please check your inventory.*
pocket:
You try to look for an indescript object.
You aren't quite sure why.

You dumped everything you owned before
coming here, remember?
pocket_yes: It's a hard thing to forget, isn't it?

You continue forth, not allowing empty pockets
to hinder your travel.
pocket_no: Oh. Well, you did. And now you know.

You continue forth, not allowing empty pockets
to hinder your travel.
grotto:
One tree, its wood blackand sickly, stands as
the centerpiece in a small grotto.

Its roots, which reach out some thirty feet
or so in all directions, form a perfect circle
around the trunk.

This clearing, allowing you a view of the sky,
sits in silence. The whistling of wind shakes
the leaves of the old wood.
grotto_investigate:
The tree stands unmoving before you.
Slowly and methodically carving a path to the
dirt below, amber resin leaks from the old wood.

The air is silent around you, the fog kept
on the outskirts of this small grotto.
What do you want to do?
grotto_wifeFinally:
You're sitting on your couch, the leather old
and cracking. Your wife sits next to you,
her gaze undecipherable.
grotto_wifeSilence:
"Listen, if you don't feel like talking, that's fine.
Just please don't ignore me." She continues,
a hint of annoyance in her voice.

She's doing her best to hide it, but you know
her well enough. She's dealt with this before.
How are you going to respond?
grotto_apologeticWife:
She stares at you for a moment before
nodding her head.

"We were talking about Adalade. You said
you finally got her into that preschool, right?
The one next to the Dennys?"
What do you want to say?
grotto_lieToWife:
"Do you think you can take her then?
On your way to work?"
grotto_wifeNoPreschool:
She nods in understanding. You know the look.
You've seen it before.

The hint of disappointment.
The attempt to hide it. 
It's routine.
backToGrotto:
A strong gust of wind forces you back to
the grotto. A chill runs through your spin.
grotto_holyShit:
"Holy fucking shit. You did not
leave our daughter at school again."
A deafening silence follows her words.

Then, the shuffling of feet, dangling of keys,
and the closing of a front door
all follow in quick succession.
grotto_yellAtWife:
You yell as she leaves. Suddenly out of breath,
you find yourself heaving for air.
grotto_breathingExercise:
You take a breath.
You remember how to do this, right?

It's the box breathing method.
You know, 4-4-4-4?

You spend sixteen seconds breathing.
Yes, exactly sixteen.
grotto_punchTree:
You punch the tree.
It deserved it probably.
Your hand stings with disapproval.

Anger fills your body. Your time in the
forest hasn't brought you the peace
of mind you had hoped it would.
grotto_sit:
It dawns on you that you're wasting
your time here.

"Honey, did you pick up Adalade from school?"
Your wife calls from the living room.

You didn't. She got out of school two hours
ago. You've been sitting on this couch since
you woke up.
How are you going to respond?
grotto_leave:
You leave the grotto in the past, turning to
contnue your pursuit of the distant tower,
its spires reaching far into the gray
overcast above.

The sounds of the fauna echo throughout
the region.

To be continued...
grotto_leavePartOne:
You turn to leave from the grotto, only to
see an unrecognizable assortment of trees
and forest behind you.
You are totally and completely lost.
grotto_leavePartTwo:
A sudden and complete sense of dread and
paranoia overcome you as you return to
the grotto.

For some reason, you feel as though you just
danced with death.
grotto_end:
Deciding to throw your responbilities and
obligations thrown to the wind, you live out
the rest of your days in the forest.

FIN - I tried, but what else can change me?


*Continue to go back to Menu*
creekStart:
The sound of running water begins to fill
your ears as you spot a small
river cutting the forest in two.

A bridge connects the ten foot gap
between you and the land opposite the river.
It's wooden floorboards sway and rattle gently with the wind.

This bridge hasn't been maintained in some time.
Droplets of water drip from its wood, as though it has just been misted.

It beckons you to cross the chasm.
As you peer below, over the edge, you quickly note the distance to be fifteen feet, give or take a foot.
It would not be a pleasant fall.
cussAtWorld:
Your wife stands, staring at you.
Unflinching.
Her gaze stern and focused.

You are in your garage,
sunlight flooding in from the open door that
allows a view into the empty street.

"Is that all?"She asks you.
The tone is piercing.
yesIsThatAll:
Her expression recoils slightly,
caught off-guard by your answer.

"Well in that case, I'm done here.
You need to figure your shit out,
because you can't just be cussing at me like that."
"I deserve better. I'm here for you, but I'm not here to be your punching bag."

She sighs.
This is a conversation she's had many times over.

"You know what? I...Just. Nevermind. Figure your shit out, okay?" She asks,
turning and leaving the garage.
Your car sits expectantly in the room.
noIsThatAll: The moment you begin to speak, your wife interrupts you.

"No? What the fuck do you mean no?
 Do you honestly think I'm just going to fucking sit here while you yell at me
 in my own garage?

"Do you think I have the TIME to do that?
For YOU of all people? You've got to be joke, right?"

"Oh, this is rich. I'll tell you what,
you can tell your friends you got to stroke your little ego
one last time before I left you."
"I'm sure that'll fix the gaping hole in your heart."
The door slams as she leaves.
For the first time, you are alone.
Your car sits expectantly in the room.
sayNothingIsThatAll:
"You can't keep doing this."
 She sighs.

"You can't just explode and then stay silent
as though that solves the problem.
I do not deserve this."

She speaks,
"Get your shit together, alright?
I said I'd be there for you, but I'm not here to be your punching bag.

"Not talking to me doesn't solve the problem.
 Bottling up doesn't solve the problem."

A deep exhale escapes from her nose
as she turns to leave.
"And Adalade doesn't deserve this either. Figure your shit out."
Your car sits expectantly in the room.
theSceneBeforeTheGameStarts:
Without hesitation, you enter your vehicle,
slamming the reverse as you exit your home.

The highway offers little respite as you pass person after person,
their cars becoming blurs on the wayside.

An exit, one that, to your knowledge,
has just finished construction, appears up ahead.
bridgeCrossing:
You approach the bridge, placing your hands on its posts,
each of which are staked deep into the earth.

You step forward, the wooden floorboards creaking beneath you.
The bridge holds your weight.
You allow yourself a breath of relief.

A gust of wind forces you to steel your grip.
You feel your hands tighten around the rope handles
 of the bridge as it rattles with the breeze.
walkAcrossBridge:
You take your steps slowly,
careful to not step on any portions of clearly rotted wood.

The bridge rattles as you step,
some of the floorboards shifting slightly beneath your weight.

Before long, you have found yourself
on the other side of the river, the forest covered in fog behind you.

A breeze sways the treetops.
The soft sound of leaves brushing against leaves fills the air.

The tower, ever so close,
stands fortified in the ground.
It appears your journey is nearing an end.
takeABreakAtBridge:
You feel calmer.
The tightness in your chest mellows slightly as you take a breath.
The forest offers a moment of brevity and peace.
The air is cold against your nose, forcing a sniffle.

A squirrel passing underfoot catches your attention
before disappearing high into one of the trees.
You are alone, but at least there's company.
goodEnding:
You begin the ascent of the spiral staircase, small windows adorning the its sides,
allowing you glimpses into the outside world as you climb.

Your legs are heavy, weary from the journey.
The fog seems to recede the higher you climb,
the forest becoming more and more visible
as you trek further up the tower

You climb for what seems like ages, soon finding that the top of this
tower has long since been destroyed.
Or perhaps, it was never completed.

It stands half-constructed. As you peer below,
you find that the ground is a great distance below you.

You stand at the half-constructed peak of this tower,
gazing at the forest and its surroundings.

A familiar grotto, noticeable by the forest clearing, sways below you.
The sounds of the fauna appear to be dying down as the sunn
wanes below the horizon in the distance.

A single lighthouse, sitting on a rock formation just past the coast,
has begun to spin its light in a familiar rhythm.

You feel at ease as you stare at this view.
The forest sways in delight.
The sun begins to dip over the horizon.
badEnding:
You begin the ascent of the spiral staircase,
small windows adorning the its sides,
allowing you glimpses into the outside world as you climb.

Your legs are heavy, weary from the journey.
The fog outside seems to completely engulf the base of the tower.

In other words, below you is a sea of fog,
the gray of the clouds staionary above you.

You climb for what seems like ages, soon finding that the top of this
tower has long since been destroyed.
Or perhaps, it was never completed.

It stands half-constructed. As you peer below,
you find that the ground is a great distance below you.
Looking up, the forest and its surroundings remain drenched in fog.

The coast gently waves in the distance,
a singular lighthouse planting on a rock formation in the water
spins its focused light in a familiar rhythm.
Ever so faintly, you hear the sound of waves crashing on rock.

he forest offers you this view,
however, a waning sun in the distance,
ducking under the horizon, indicates that it is not to last.
